name: Marketplace buyerâ€“seller collusion
red_flags: High order volume between a small set of counterparties.
Many orders quickly refunded or cancelled.
Shared devices/IPs or addresses across buyer and seller accounts.
recommended_checks: Link buyers and sellers via device, IP, address, and payment instruments.
Compare order and refund ratios vs peer sellers in the same category.
Review shipping and delivery evidence, including courier tracking and POD.
Check internal notes or messages for indications of off-platform coordination.
sar_str_angles: Explain why the pattern suggests collusion instead of legitimate repeat business.
Quantify total suspicious order and refund value.
Highlight any cross-border flows or rapid settlements to external accounts.

country_notes.GLOBAL: Pattern broadly aligns with typical collusion indicators under a risk-based AML framework.
country_notes.IN: Indian platforms/payment providers often consider such collusion as abuse of marketplace and cashback programmes, requiring enhanced monitoring.
country_notes.EU: EU institutions may treat such behaviour as fraud/abuse impacting both consumers and platforms under AMLD risk-based obligations.
country_notes.US: US platforms may consider this under fraud/abuse and potential money laundering if proceeds are layered through accounts.

pitfalls: Do not assume all repeat purchases are collusion; contextualize with product type and marketing campaigns.
Shared devices/IPs can reflect family or shared-office use; check full context.

name: Friendly fraud / chargeback abuse
red_flags: Spike in chargebacks on specific SKUs or merchants.
Disputes concentrated on certain geographies or BINs.
Cardholder has history of similar disputes across multiple merchants.
recommended_checks: Review transaction history of the cardholder across time.
Inspect merchant descriptors, MCC codes, and product types involved.
Check 3DS/SCA logs, AVS/CVV results, and other authentication factors.
Collect and review delivery proof, invoices, and merchant communication.
sar_str_angles: Describe pattern of repeated disputes indicating potential intentional abuse.
Quantify actual and potential loss exposure from the pattern.
Highlight any collusive merchants or unusual refund patterns.

country_notes.GLOBAL: Chargeback abuse is usually handled via card scheme rules; SAR filing is considered when patterns suggest organized or repeated fraud.

pitfalls: Do not treat every chargeback as fraud; separate merchant quality issues from abuse.
Consider consumer protection rules and regulatory expectations on fair treatment.

name: Mule / pass-through account
red_flags: Multiple incoming credits from unrelated counterparties within short time windows.
Rapid cash-outs or outward transfers, leaving low end-of-day balances.
No clear economic purpose consistent with customer profile.
recommended_checks: Profile the customer (occupation, KYC data, stated transaction purpose).
Cluster counterparties and look for common devices, IPs, or merchants.
Review historical behaviour before and after suspicious period.
Check for links to known fraud, scam, or crypto off-ramps.
sar_str_angles: Explain why behaviour resembles pass-through activity inconsistent with profile.
Quantify volume and velocity of suspicious flows.
Highlight risk of the account being used as a mule in broader fraud schemes.

country_notes.GLOBAL: Mule/pass-through accounts are a common indicator of broader fraud or scam operations and often warrant SAR/STR consideration.

pitfalls: Do not assume all fragmented payments are mule activity; consider gig-economy patterns.
Avoid mirror imaging; some markets have naturally high payment fragmentation.
